name: Length scale factor in similar shapes 3

skills.name: Identify whether two shapes are similar or not
Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one
Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the shorter one
Understand that an enlargement of a shape does not change the size of angles

explanations.A: These two triangles are similar because the sides are enlarged by the same scale factor: 7.5 ÷ 5 = 1.5 and 12 ÷ 8 = 1.5.
explanations.B: Think carefully about the angle placement here. These shapes are isosceles triangles. Which angles will therefore be the same?
explanations.C: You have found a shape with 2 sides which are in the same proportion as our original shape, but think carefully about their placement. In our original triangle, the longest length was between the 2 base angles. Is this the same with your chosen shape?
explanations.D: I think you might have added 1cm to each length, but this does not keep them in proportion. Instead we need to multiply each length by the same number.

explanations.A: The scale factor is 15 ÷ 5 = 3. So the side of the large triangle (x + y) should be 3 times the small triangle x. So the small side represents 1 part and the large side represents 3 parts. This means y would represent 2 parts as it is the difference between the small and large sides. So we have 1 part to 2 parts which gives the ratio 1 : 2.
explanations.B: I think you have worked out the correct scale factor. This would give the ratio 1:3 of the side of the small triangle to the side of the large triangle. But does y represent the whole side of the large triangle?
explanations.C: Not quite. Start by finding the scale factor to get from the smaller triangle to the larger triangle. Then have a think about what y represents.

explanations.A: The scale factor is the longer side divided by the shorter side when using the equivalent sides on the similar shapes. The scale factor is therefore b / a. Since we have the longer side and want to find a shorter side we would need to divide by the scale factor. So ? = c ÷ (b/a).
explanations.B: We don't need numerical values to work this out, but you could replace the letters with numbers to help work out what to do.
explanations.C: I think you have found the scale factor the wrong way around. We must divide the length of the larger shape by the length of the smaller shape.
explanations.D: I think you have correctly found the scale factor (b/a) but then multiplied it by c. The side we are finding is smaller than c so do we need to multiply by the scale factor? Or do something else?
